definitions.definition: a creature that is covered with feathers and has two wings and two legs. Most birds can fly.

examples.text: a bird’s nest with two eggs in it
Birds were singing in the trees.
The area has a wealth of bird life.
More than a third of Britain's **bird species** need urgent protection.

definitions.definition: a person of a particular type, especially somebody who is strange or unusual in some way

examples.text: She is that rare bird: a politician with a social conscience.

definitions.definition: an offensive way of referring to a young woman
to not be important or practical
it is better to keep something that you already have than to risk losing it by trying to get much more
the basic facts about sex, especially as told to children
a view of something from a high position looking down

examples.text: From the plane we had a bird's-eye view of Manhattan.

definitions.definition: people of the same sort (are found together)
the person who takes the opportunity to do something before other people will have an advantage over them
to shout at somebody to show that you do not like or approve of them; to be shouted at
to make a rude sign at somebody with your middle finger; to have this sign made at you
to achieve two things at the same time with one action
used to say that somebody told you something but you do not want to say who it was

wordOrigin: Old English brid ‘chick, fledgling’, of unknown origin.
